posts.name: Jan Carlos Morales
posts.cooked:
Hi everyone, I have a dumb doubt about, Is there possible to get the program that someone had loaded on the roborio without having that program?

My doubt is because, in this time on quarantine the program on the robot is changing everytime when people go any day, and an accident could happen if we don’t know what the program does, so to be secure what the program had been running, it would be great to see the code.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
Unfortunately, the answer is likely “no”.

For most programming languages, the actual files you edit are compiled into a binary format the Rio can actually run. This is a one-way transformation, it’s not possible to uncompile the exact code back to it’s source.

The roboRIO 2.0 does offer a removable SD card which you can use to make easy backups of a known-good configuration.

The best practice is to use a version control tool like Git, and ensure content is saved to a online repository (like github)

posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked:
If there’s any doubt what code is on the robot, redeploy code. As @gerthworm says, using source control like git (and GitHub) is a good idea. Learn how to make branches. That way you can checkout a known good branch and redeploy to the robot.

Our team makes a new branch before each competition so we can track fixes applied during a competition weekend. Later when we have more time, we can review, test, and clean up those changes before merging back to the main branch.

We also keep a separate “demo” branch we can deploy to the robot. Usually with lower speeds and “dangerous” autonomous routines disabled. This branch is for driving the robot at outreaches and when handing the controls to a new driver or operator.

posts.name: Mr.R^2
posts.cooked: In Python, this is possible. In fact, we have done it using win scp. Python loads robot.py directly into the Rio. However, I think this is the only option other than with the Rio2.0 and taking an image. Even then, with an image, I do not think you could easily edit the code, but you could copy it directly.

posts.name: bobbysq
posts.cooked:
Mr.R_2:

Even then, with an image, I do not think you could easily edit the code, but you could copy it directly.

You probably won’t be able to get anything useful out of the compiled binary even with the RIO 2, no. But with the expanded storage you get with the SD card, it would be feasible to modify the deploy script to also upload a copy of the source code to the RIO’s storage, though proper version control would be preferable.

posts.name: Chris Gerth
posts.cooked:
While I won’t say this is a good idea, I have to wonder… Could you run a git repo of your source code on the Rio, run a remote VS Code server that development laptops could hook to, and have actions or hooks on commit which build and run the code?

I don’t think it’s a wise answer given the current hardware capabilities… But maybe theoretically possible?

posts.name: tkchan
posts.cooked: I would suggested that your mentor work out some sort of configuration controls with you guys.  and everyone should be deploying code in parallel to either to Github or some other repository.  [They don’t necessarily have to do it on every upload/test on the robot code but should do it at the end of ‘an’ activity period at a min].
